===Etymology 1===
From {{der|en|la|cum||[[with]]}}.

====Preposition====
{{en-prep}}

# {{non-gloss definition|Used in indicating a thing with two roles, functions, or natures, or a thing that has changed from one to another.}}
#: {{ux|en|He built a bus-'''cum'''-greenhouse that made a bold statement, but the plants in it didn't live very long.}}
#* {{quote-book|en|year=1926-1950|author=[[w:George Bernard Shaw|George Bernard Shaw]]|title=Collected Letters: 1926-1950|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=UF08AAAAIAAJ|publisher=University of California/Viking|year_published=1985|page=31|passage=He is too good an actor to need that sort of tomfoolery: the effect will be far better if he is a credible mining camp elder-'''cum'''-publican.}}
#* {{quote-journal|en|year=2001|month=Nov/Dec|author=David Sachs|title=LET THEM EAT BITS|journal=American Spectator|volume=34|issue=8|page=78|passage=The banner shows a yellowed silhouette of a boy (possibly Calvin, of Calvin & Hobbes) urinating on an EU flag. Sites such as this show the full power of the Internet as a propaganda medium '''cum''' travel service '''cum''' organizing tool. Oh, and nightlife directory.}}

====Conjunction====
{{en-con}}

# {{non-gloss definition|1=Used in indicating a thing with two or more roles, functions, or natures, or a thing that has changed from one to another.}}
#: {{ux|en|But instead of being a salesperson '''cum''' barista '''cum''' waitress merely serving the wordsmiths, I'm one of them, reading her latest baby out loud.}}

====Usage notes====
Many style guides and editors recommend the spelling ''[[come]]'' for verb uses (''to orgasm''/''to ejaculate'') while strictly allowing the spelling ''cum'' for the noun (''semen''/''female ejaculatory discharge''). Both spellings are sometimes found in either the noun or verb sense, however. Others prefer to distinguish in formality, using ''come'' for any formal usage and ''cum'' only in slang, erotic or pornographic contexts.<ref>[http://www.glossophilia.org/?p=4925 Glossophilia]</ref>

===Etymology 2===
From Old Latin {{m|la|quom}}, from {{der|la|ine-pro|*kʷóm}}, accusative of {{m|ine-pro|*kʷos}}, {{m|ine-pro|*kʷis}}. Compare its feminine form {{m|la|quam}} (as in {{m|la|tum}}-{{m|la|tam}}).

====Alternative forms====
* {{l|la|quum}}
* {{qualifier|Old Latin}} {{l|la|quom}}{{attention|itc-ola}}

====Conjunction====
{{head|la|conjunction|+ subjunctive}}

# [[when]]
# [[because]]
# [[although]]

=====Usage notes=====
* In the sense of [[when]], if there is no causal link between the verb in the dependent clause and the verb in the main clause (sometimes called an inverted cum-clause, as the 'main action' of the sentence occurs in the dependent clause), the indicative is used rather than the subjunctive.
*: ''per viam ambulābāmus cum pugnam vīdimus.'' [not ''*vīderīmus''] — "We were walking through the street when we happened to witness a fight."
